Steam 42 / Biomass Installations
The Babcock & Wilcox Company
As electrical demand grows, power plant developers 
as well as existing plant owners are utilizing biomass 
as an alternative to fossil fuels. To meet carbon dioxide 
(CO2) reduction targets and to reduce fossil fuel depen­
dency, policymakers in many countries are encouraging 
increased biomass-fired energy production.
Biomass energy production is widespread throughout 
the world. Biomass is a readily available renewable energy 
source derived from organic material. Predominantly, 
biomass fuels originate from wood-processing residues 
and are utilized in hundreds of commercial operations. 
Biomass is a dispatchable fuel, meaning harvested 
biomass can be stockpiled and available to meet energy 
demands. This makes biomass more reliable than wind 
and solar for electricity production. Biomass is also a 
renewable energy solution in areas where wind, solar or 
hydro energy are not readily available.
Biomass fuels are classified as closed loop or open loop. 
A closed loop biomass fuel is defined as any organic plant 
grown as high yield energy crop. Examples of closed loop 
feedstock are switchgrass and eucalyptus. Closed loop 
biomass projects are often structured around long-term 
fuel supply contracts that support plant economics. 
However, the vast majority of biomass power generation 
today is open loop meaning biomass is obtained from a 
variety of regional supply sources.
Many technologies are available to transform raw 
biomass material directly or indirectly into process steam 
and/or electricity. These technologies include direct firing, 
co-firing with another fuel, gasification, torrefaction and 
pelletization. Most current biomass power generators 
are direct fired and produce 50 MW or less of electricity. 
Plants are owned and operated by various stakeholders, 
from industrial users, e.g., pulp and paper mills and 
lumber companies, to power utilities and independent 
power producers.
As a fuel, biomass is not without challenges and in 
some instances it can be more difficult to burn than 
coal. Understanding and controlling biomass moisture 
and ash content is important. Integrating biomass 
into a fuel mix requires careful consideration of firing 
technologies, steam cycle conditions, tube materials, 
material handling, and emissions control systems.
Spurred by Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) or 
Renewable Energy Standards (RES), impending carbon 
legislation, and public concerns about the environment, 
power producers throughout the world are considering 
alternatives to lower emissions and incorporate more

renewable energy into their electricity generation mix. 
While wind, solar and other renewable energy sources 
are viable options, utilities may find biomass attractive 
due to feedstock proximity and availability, reliability and 
cost of generation. The key is to thoroughly understand 
long-term fuel supply infrastructure and cost, combustion 
technologies, and the required environmental systems. 
A repowering project adds further complexity as existing 
equipment must be assessed for new, and perhaps more 
challenging, operating conditions.
Biomass Supply Chain
The biomass supply chain differs from coal. Fig. 
1 illustrates the biomass resource availability in the 
United States (U.S.).1 Biomass lacks the consistency of 
coal because biomass fuels can originate from multiple 
sources with widely variable properties, such as particle 
size, moisture content, contaminants, degrees of decom­
position, and seasonal availability. Biomass combustion 
technologies therefore must be fuel flexible and be able to 
accommodate feedstock variety. The following are some 
common biomass fuel sources.
Woody biomass represents one of the most read­
ily accessible biomass fuel sources. (See Fig. 2.) Woody 
biomass residues originate from forest thinning or timber 
harvesting, pulping processes, lumber manufacture and 
furniture production.
In-forest residues (also known as slash) include 
waste from timber harvesting, forest management and 
clearing operations. Slash includes treetops, limbs, 
bark and commercially unacceptable trees. Mechanical 
overgrowth thinning is expensive and presents collection 
and transportation challenges. Further, the use of slash 
as a feedstock requires a fuel yard and feed system that 
can accommodate variability. Regardless, slash is a viable 
fuel source, but requires the power plant to be in close 
proximity to the harvesting operations.
Agricultural wastes are farming industry byproducts. 
Agricultural wastes such as pits, shells, hulls, orchard 
prunings, bagasse, corn stover, straw, or other field stalks 
are suitable biomass fuels but also present challenges. 
(See Fig. 3.) Agricultural wastes have the disadvantage 
of seasonality and competition from farming operations. 
In addition, the ash characteristics of silage and other 
agricultural wastes can result in boiler cleanability and 
corrosion issues.
Energy crops are grown specifically as a fuel. Hybrid 
crops are being developed to maximize yield, time to

harvest and utilization of nonfood production acreage. 
Species include miscantus, switchgrass, sorghum, 
arundo and eucalyptus to name a few. Experience with 
planting and harvesting hybrid crops as a renewable fuel 
is limited. Like agricultural wastes, ash characteristics 
may be problematic.
Opportunity fuels are comprised of yard trimmings, 
construction and demolition waste, scrap pallets, packag­
ing, furniture, or other discarded wood-based debris. 
The disadvantage of opportunity fuels is the residual 
chemicals that may be part of the waste which affect 
ash chemistry, ash fusion temperature and products of 
combustion. Urban waste has the advantage of offsetting 
landfill disposal costs.
Pelletizing is a process that converts biomass into a fuel 
with coal-like properties. Pellets are formed in a process 
that dries, mills, conditions and extrudes the biomass to 
the end product. (See Fig. 4.) A variety of biomass feed­
stocks can be used. The process grinds oversized material 
and compacts the fine feedstock into a homogeneous, 
dense, high energy fuel. The parent feedstock material 
and manufacturing process define the fuel’s properties. If 
the pellets are derived from agricultural waste or energy 
crops, then the ash properties may impose combustion

limitations. Biomass pellets contain low moisture, are 
clean, and are easy to handle and transport. Pellets are 
considered a proven biomass technology and a convenient 
fuel for co-firing with coal. An initial pellet size reduction, 
typically using hammer mills, may be required if final 
combustion sizing is achieved with existing pulverizers. 
Biomass pellets must be sheltered from the weather as 
they will swell and decompose when exposed to moisture 
and humidity. For this reason, pellets are stored indoors 
rather than in an open fuel yard. Covered pellet storage 
is therefore an additional fuel handling system cost.
Torrefied wood is processed biomass with superior 
handling and co-firing capabilities as compared to pellets. 
Harvested biomass is heated in the absence of oxygen to 
remove moisture and volatiles. The biomass decomposes 
into a brittle, nonfibrous, uniform char product with a 
heating value approaching that of coal. The char is then 
processed into pellets. Torrefied pellets are hydrophobic, 
i.e., they do not absorb water, and thus, can be stored 
outdoors and handled like coal. Their brittleness improves 
grindability, allowing co-firing with coal at rates greater 
than nontorrefied pellets. The ability to handle and store 
torrefied biomass, being much like coal, can significantly 
reduce the capital cost required for a co-firing conversion 
of an existing coal-fired plant.
Biomass Characteristics
Biomass is a renewable fuel that can be combusted 
using a variety of technologies. Each installation must 
address the issues and challenges related to fuel avail­
ability, seasonal changes, material handling, combustion, 
emissions control and operational constraints. A 
biomass-powered facility must balance equipment and 
location with innovative strategies to achieve high plant 
efficiency and required emissions with low capital and 
operating costs.
Availability
In the U.S., biomass is readily available in most parts 
of the country primarily as woody biomass consisting of 
slash, mill residue, bark and wood not suitable for pulping. 
(See Fig. 1.) Much like coal, as demand increases, the 
biomass supply will more likely be locked into long-term 
contracts. Other plentiful biomass fuel resources include 
switchgrass, corn stover, corn cobs and other waste 
streams like refuse-derived fuels, waste paper, cardboard, 
etc. The ability to fire a diverse feedstock requires a well 
designed fuel handling system. Failure to address fuel 
variability can result in operational limitations, forced 
outages and lost revenue.
Agricultural waste tends to be seasonally available 
while forest harvesting products and slash (nonvalue 
trees, tree tops, and branches) are available throughout 
the year. If a steady, reliable source of biomass is not 
readily available, a power plant may be forced to utilize op­
portunity fuels. Properties of such fuels may vary widely. 
Agricultural waste material may contain constituents 
from fertilizer that may be corrosive or promote boiler 
slagging and fouling. Construction and demolition wastes 
can contain contaminants that increase regulated air 
emissions. A thorough understanding of fuel character­
istics is necessary.
Fuel handling and storage
Although harvested biomass can be delivered by barge 
or rail, truck delivery is the most common. (See Fig. 5.) 
When delivering by truck, the volume of truck traffic is 
the most visible part of the operation and the road delivery 
infrastructure must be able to handle the traffic. For 
example, a 50 MW unit will require approximately 100 
trucks per day. Biomass-fired systems of 50 MW or less 
typically have the advantage of using locally sourced 
wood, drawing from a 50-mile radius which helps defray 
transportation costs. Beyond this distance, transporta­
tion logistics become prohibitive.
Wood chips have relatively low mass heating value 
and low bulk density that combine to significantly 
reduce its volumetric heating value. As a result, more 
fuel is required and wider belt conveyors are necessary 
to deliver and store the energy equivalent to other solid 
fuels. Plants firing wood chips, for example, require eight 
times the volume of bituminous coal on a Btu/ft3 (kJ/m3) 
basis. The increased storage, processing and handling 
system space required can become significant for large 
biomass-fired plants.
Fuel handling system design is a key technical 
requirement for biomass fuels. Controlling fuel quality

by processing or blending biomass on site is standard 
fuel yard practice. Screens and hogs are typically used to 
control particle size. Blending is important for controlling 
properties and characteristics. For co-firing applications, 
the properties of biomass, coal and possibly other solid 
fuels can be blended. The objective is to meet the combus­
tion, emissions and economic constraints.
The removal of tramp material is a necessary step 
to improve biomass quality and consistency. Nonferrous 
metal separation, magnetic separators and screens must 
be used to prepare the biomass. Rocks, debris, metals 
and other contaminants should not be fed directly to 
the boiler.
Wood chips, slash and other agricultural products 
have poor material handling characteristics. Biomass fuel 
particles compress, mat and become entwined when piled 
or placed in a bin. Biomass blends can have very poor flow 
characteristics. Particle size, shape and compressibility 
all contribute to this phenomenon. To promote movement, 
bins are often designed with negative slope wall angles, 
wider at the bottom than at the top. Material conveyance 
must be carefully considered when choosing chute angles 
and liner materials.
Storing large volumes of biomass fuel is another 
challenge. Wet biomass (>60% moisture) does not pose a 
spontaneous combustion hazard, but it will degrade due to 
biological activity. At moisture levels between 20 and 60%, 
typical for most biomass fueled plants, both degradation 
and spontaneous combustion are concerns. Biomass 
particle surface area and irregular shape provide a near 
ideal environment for fiber breakdown, biological heating 
and spontaneous combustion. Conversely, dry biomass 
(<20% moisture) is relatively stable and can be stored 
for long periods of time.
Fuel Properties
Proper combustion technology selection requires 
representative fuel analyses, ash mineral analyses, 
and expected seasonal variation of the fuel. Biomass 
fuels are generally characterized by proximate and 
ultimate analyses and gross calorific value according to 
ASTM-E870. Ash elemental analyses can be evaluated 
according to different ASTM standards. (See Chapter 
9.) Fuel and ash analyses should be obtained for every 
representative fuel source to identify constituents that 
may be detrimental to the boiler and ancillary equipment. 
Table 1 provides typical proximate, ultimate and ash 
analyses for select biomass fuels.
Moisture
Typical moisture content values of biomass range 
between 20 and 60%. On a dry basis, biomass fuels have 
more volatiles and a greater hydrogen-to-carbon ratio 
than coals, making them more reactive. This means 
biomass can be fired efficiently if sufficiently dry. Caution 
is necessary because spontaneous combustion during 
handling and storage is a potential hazard. To fire 
any wet waste fuel, energy is required to evaporate the 
moisture. Combustion calculation methods are discussed 
in Chapter 10. The moisture from fuel loss is one of the 
most significant heat losses when calculating boiler 
efficiency for biomass fuels.
Fuel constituents
Fuel constituents dictate combustion air require­
ments, flue gas flow rates, uncontrolled emissions, and 
the heat distribution between the radiant and convection 
sections. These parameters will vary as the fuel varies. 
The influence of biomass constituents on boiler design, 
efficiency, heat transfer effectiveness, and environmental 
impact is presented in Table 2.
Biomass has low inherent ash, but when harvesting 
wood or other bio-crops, incidental ash is often picked 
up in the form of sand from dragging timber, dirt from 
roots, etc. Also, soil conditions or coastal locations may 
promote an increase in alkalis and chlorine that may 
cause corrosion. Chlorine can originate from salt in the 
soil, by floating logs in salt water, road salt, or by growing 
crops in brackish water. Some biomass has naturally 
high chlorine content, particularly new, green growth. 
When chlorine content exceeds 0.1%, superheater tube 
metallurgy must be carefully selected.
Agricultural-based fuels (nonwoody biomass) are 
often considered difficult for combustion. This is 
especially true for straw, which contains high concentra­
tions of silica, potassium and chlorine. When straw is 
combusted, condensation of potassium chloride results 
in ash deposition and high temperature corrosion. Straw 
has a high ash content (3 to 10%) compared to woody 
biomass, making ash removal a challenge. Straw ash 
has a relatively low melting point often resulting in 
slag formation.
Biomass fuel can be high in chlorine, but is typically 
low in sulfur. Sulfur tends to moderate the affect of 
chlorine and a sulfur-to-chlorine ratio greater than 2.0 
is generally desired. The combination of high chlorine, 
alkalis and some sulfur forms a low melting (often 
molten phase), highly corrosive eutectic that can reduce 
superheater life.
Fuel sizing
Fuel preparation requirements are driven by the 
combustion process, primarily furnace residence time. 
Furnace residence time is necessary for complete combus­
tion of gaseous products and char burnout. Particle mass, 
size, shape and volatile content are key parameters to 
consider. Each combustion technology has a preferred 
fuel size distribution. Mass firing technologies, such as 
grate-fired and bubbling fluidized-bed (BFB) boilers, have 
long furnace residence times and can accommodate larger 
[4 to 6 in. (102 to 152 mm)], as-delivered fuel particles. 
Too many fine particle sizes may promote excessive 
carryover. Co-firing biomass with coal requires a fine 
particle size less than 0.0625 in. (2 mm) due to the short 
furnace residence times associated with pulverized coal 
(PC)-fired boilers. If grassy fuel is in the co-firing mix, 
it should be limited to 2 in. (50 mm) in length maximum 
because it is difficult to pulverize.
The goal is to provide an even fuel size distribution 
within the manufacturer’s specified design range. 
Incomplete combustion reduces boiler efficiency and leads 
to higher fuel feed rates and increased unburned carbon 
(UBC) in the furnace and downstream ash collection 
hoppers. UBC in the ash may increase the potential for 
hopper, economizer, air heater, precipitator and/or fabric 
filter fires, as well as ash disposal issues.

Emissions
Once fuel has been determined, gaseous emissions 
must be considered. Uncontrolled emissions should be 
evaluated first, followed by post-combustion emissions 
control options. The combustion technology must be 
matched with air emissions control systems. Carbon 
monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) are two criteria 
pollutants that are dependent upon the chosen combustion 
technology and should be considered simultaneously. 
Multiple combustion and post-combustion technology 
scenarios are typically evaluated to determine the most 
cost-effective arrangement.
Combustion Technologies
Biomass combustion begins with the evaporation of 
moisture in the fuel. This vaporizing process absorbs 
heat available within the furnace. This heat loss is the 
water from fuel loss in efficiency calculations. Following 
evaporation is pyrolysis. Here, the fuel is devolatilized 
and the gasified products oxidize and burn. The final 
phase is char burnout where the dry, devolatilized fixed 
carbon is oxidized and burned to completion. There are 
many commercial technologies available to accomplish 
the combustion process. They are typically classified as 
direct or indirect. In direct firing, the fuel is burned and 
the direct energy release is utilized to generate steam 
for process industries or power generation. Indirect 
combustion interrupts the combustion process at the 
gasification stage. The indirectly gasified products are 
collected as a synthetic gas (syngas) and transported to 
a boiler or gas turbine for combustion.
Direct firing
Direct firing is the most common combustion technol­
ogy used for steam generation from biomass. Direct firing 
includes grate (or stoker) firing (Chapter 16), bubbling

30-6
Steam 42 / Biomass Installations
The Babcock & Wilcox Company
fluidized-bed and circulating fluidized-bed (CFB) 
technologies (Chapter 17), and suspension or pulverized 
fuel firing (Chapter 14). Grate-fired, BFB and CFB boilers 
are proven biomass firing technologies. (See Figs. 6, 7 
and 8.) Fuel preferences for each combustion technology 
are shown in Fig. 9.
The majority of new biomass boiler installations are 100 
MW or less, as driven by fuel availability, transportation 
and handling. Most new direct-fired units utilize grate, 
BFB or CFB technology. With the increased demand 
for renewable energy, power generators are evaluating 
existing pulverized coal-, oil- or gas-fired boilers to assess 
biomass firing capability. A viable biomass conversion 
strategy is to co-combust biomass with pulverized coal. 
In such an application, biomass is typically limited to no 
more than 20% of the fuel heat input. For higher input 
rates, a more capital intensive approach is to retrofit a 
grate or BFB to an existing PC-fired unit. This strategy 
has several advantages. Fuel sizing requirements are 
more generous. Fuel handling is simpler and the unit 
can have up to 100% biomass firing capability. When 
retrofitting a grate or BFB bottom, one alternative is 
to support the combustion technology off of the existing 
furnace walls whereby the structural loads of the retrofit 
are carried to the top steel. Another alternative is to 
independently bottom support the new grate or BFB, 
so that new loads are not added to existing structural 
steel. The limiting retrofit parameter is typically flue 
gas velocities or furnace residence time. Firing biomass, 
especially high moisture biomass, can have gas weights 
30 to 50% greater than coal. Since convection pass 
velocities increase proportionally, high gas velocities 
may cause erosion from particulate carryover. With 60 
ft/s (18.3 m/s) convection pass velocities, a 30% reduction 
from maximum continuous rating (MCR) can be expected 
when firing biomass.
Grate firing  Grate- (stoker) fired boilers are the 
oldest commercial combustion technology still in use 
today. (See Fig. 6.) There are several grate types which 
are capable of firing biomass. Smaller, lower cost 
bottom-supported 15 to 25 MW boilers are common while 
top-supported, grate-fired biomass boilers up to 150 MW 
are also in operation. Grate-fired boilers are suitable for 
many types of fuels including coal, wood, peat, straw, and 
other opportunity fuels, as illustrated in Fig. 9.
Fig. 7  Bubbling fluidized-bed boiler.
Fig. 6  Straw-fired boiler using grate technology.

Steam 42 / Biomass Installations
The Babcock & Wilcox Company
Modern biomass grate-fired units typically use 
water- or air-cooled vibrating grates depending on the 
fuel moisture content. (See Chapter 16.) Wood firing on 
a grate is very similar to spreader-stoker coal firing. The 
wood is fed over the fuel bed and distributed uniformly 
across the grate area. Fine particles ignite and burn in 
suspension. The coarser fuel particles fall to the grate 
and combust on a thin, fast-burning bed. Fuel is evenly 
distributed across the active grate area and combustion 
(undergrate) air is uniformly distributed through the 
grate. A portion of the total combustion air is admitted 
through ports above the grate as overfire air (OFA). It is 
important to retain a layer of ash on the grate as a shield 
from furnace radiation.
Fluidized-bed combustion  Fluidized-bed technol­
ogy (Chapter 17) is the most flexible for firing a wide 
range of fuels or fuels with variable properties. The 
choice between BFB and CFB technology depends mostly 
on boiler size and fuel choice. BFB boilers (Fig. 7) are 
preferred when firing 100% biomass or similar low-grade 
fuels with high moisture and volatile content. BFB units 
with capacities up to 100 MW have been installed. CFB 
boiler technology (Fig. 8) is generally applied to larger 
capacity units with a broad range of high fixed carbon 
fuels. Both the BFB and CFB can be configured with 
high temperature heat transfer surface (superheat and 
reheat) for improved overall cycle efficiencies.
The CFB boiler lends itself to co-firing and can fire 
a variety of solid fuels. The relatively low combustion 
temperatures, reduced fuel preparation requirements, 
and inherently low uncontrolled emissions make it well 
suited to firing low quality, high ash, high sulfur coal and 
biomass fuels. The low ash and low sulfur characteristics 
of biomass fuels make them an attractive blend with coal.
In general, grate-fired boilers and BFB boilers have 
lower capital and operating costs than CFB boilers with 
similar capacities. Grate-fired boilers have a higher toler­
ance for fuel variation (moisture, ash characteristics, size 
distribution) than BFBs or CFBs. Fluid-bed technologies 
operate with lower combustion temperatures and have 
better uncontrolled emissions than stoker units.
Suspension firing  Direct suspension firing of bio-
mass is an option for smaller, older, less efficient pulver­
ized coal-fired units. Suspension-fired boilers utilize 
burners to mix fine pulverized fuel particles and air. 
Combustion occurs in-flight rather than on a grate or in 
a fluidized bed. Biomass co-firing is the simultaneous 
combustion of biomass and other fossil fuels.
Co-firing biomass with coal provides a means of 
reducing the potential environmental impact associated 
with the combustion of fossil fuels. In many U.S. states, 
co-fired systems qualify for renewable energy credits 
and count toward meeting a state’s RPS or RES goals. 
Issues that must be considered when determining the 
feasibility of converting a unit to co-firing capability 
include the physical and chemical characteristics of the 
fuels, permitting, financing, and securing the source of 
feedstock. Co-firing is considered the most cost-effective 
technology for implementing near-term steam genera­
tion from biomass because the costs of retrofitting an 
existing plant are significantly less than building a new 
facility. A primary advantage of this technology is that 
it utilizes existing assets and infrastructure and turns 
a homogeneous fuel-based power plant into a flexible 
energy conversion facility.
Depending on the biomass constituents, biomass co-
firing can contribute from 5 to 20% of the total heat input 
needed in a pulverized coal-fired boiler without convection 
pass modifications. Typically, biomass moisture levels 
in the range of 10 to 30% are desired. High utility cycle 
steam temperatures increase the risk of corrosion when 
exposed to the corrosive flue gas. Direct suspension 
firing improves the combustion efficiency compared to 
grate or fluidized-bed combustion, but the higher energy 
consumption and complexity of the pulverizer system 
must be considered.
Biomass may be sized for combustion using existing 
coal pulverizers (mills). The term co-milling refers to 
feeding coal and biomass to the mills, grinding the fuels 
simultaneously, and then pneumatically conveying the 
pulverized blend to the burner(s). Biomass can be directly 
added to the coal feeders, but does not grind or mill the 
same as coal and typically requires much more power

The Babcock & Wilcox Company
consumption to achieve the required particle size. This 
limits the amount of biomass that can be co-fired and 
may cause a derating of unit capacity.
When co-firing biomass and coal at low input rates 
(about 2 to 3% of fuel heat input) there are fewer concerns 
related to boiler performance. But co-milling biomass, at 
even low input rates, can reduce coal fineness and thus 
increase unburned carbon. As biomass input increases, 
flame stability and turndown without igniters will 
become more difficult. Generally, biomass should be 
co-milled through all pulverizers due to increased mill 
pressure drop and recirculating load. In most cases, 
existing pulverizers will require modifications to achieve 
satisfactory particle size reduction.
Biomass can be pre-sized on site prior to pulver­
izing. This requires additional capital equipment (e.g., 
shredders and hammer mills) and separate biomass 
and coal material handling systems. Prepared biomass 
can either be fed directly to dedicated burners or to dual 
fuel burners.
Co-firing wood pellets with coal can impact both 
milling and combustion. Pellets are easy to handle but 
pulverization is limited to their inherent particle size. 
At low input rates this may be acceptable with existing 
pulverizers. If the pellets are being co-fired at high input 
rates, supplemental size reduction may be required to 
achieve a final particle size of 0.0625 in. (2 mm) or less. 
Pelletized and torrefied fuels can successfully increase 
the co-firing rate to 25 to 50%, perhaps more, with 
the proper fuel preparation and combustion system 
modifications.
Biomass can be supplied to dual fuel (coal and biomass) 
or dedicated biomass burners. Equipment layout, retrofit 
modifications and capital expenses may result in firing 
limitations and/or compromises in the design. Existing 
burners can be modified with small dedicated biomass 
nozzles, but biomass input will be limited by the size of the 
nozzle. High biomass inputs will require new burners and 
in some cases, modified furnace wall openings. The ideal 
burner is one that can co-fire biomass and pulverized coal, 
alone or in combination, within NOx and CO performance 
requirements.
Indirect firing
In contrast to direct firing where solid fuel is burned 
within the boiler, indirect firing is a co-firing or repower­
ing option where biomass is gasified (see Chapter 18) by 
an indirect system and the gas produced is delivered 
to the boiler. The gasification process is the thermal 
decomposition of biomass with little or no oxygen to yield 
a synthesis gas. The syngas is a mixture of hydrogen 
and CO. Its quality and quantity depend on the native 
biomass constituents, moisture content, temperature, 
pressure and gasification technology. Syngas heating 
values range from 100 to 500 Btu/ft3 (3700 to 18,600 kJ/
m3) and can be fired with conventional burners as a low 
heat content gas. 
The syngas is scrubbed to remove undesirable 
contaminants and is conditioned to lower sulfur and 
adjust the hydrogen-to-CO ratio prior to the boiler. The 
gasification byproducts are noncondensable gases such 
as methane and CO2, tars and high ash char. Removal 
of these contaminants reduces slagging, fouling and the 
Fig. 10  Biomass gasification installation.
corrosion risk associated with direct co-firing.
Indirect co-firing can be designed for greater fuel flex­
ibility than possible with direct co-firing or repowering 
with grate or fluidized-bed combustion technologies. This 
flexibility reduces the risk of variable biomass availability 
and price fluctuations by broadening fuel options. From 
an operations standpoint, eliminating variability will 
improve boiler stability. In a co-firing condition, market­
ability of the coal ash is not compromised. Likewise, the 
biomass ash may have a beneficial use as a fertilizer 
supplement. Fig. 10 shows a biomass gasification instal­
lation in Japan.
Combustion Considerations
Effective biomass combustion requires a thorough 
understanding of fuel moisture (efficiency), ash (slag­
ging, fouling, corrosion and erosion) and uncontrolled 
gaseous emissions. These factors can impact combustion 
efficiency, operational stability, emissions, and power 
plant maintenance. The following are some key design 
considerations.
Efficiency
Biomass moisture is vaporized during the combustion 
process. This is an energy penalty of about 1000 Btu/
lb (2326 kJ/kg) of moisture fed to the boiler which is 
significant for a typical 20 to 60% moisture biomass 
feedstock. For nearly dry biomass the penalty is tolerable. 
As fuel moisture increases, air, fuel and flue gas flow rates 
will all increase. The result is increased parasitic power 
demand (predominantly combustion fans and pulverizers) 
and increased operating and maintenance costs.
Slagging
Biomass ash containing high sodium, potassium and 
silica can combine to form a low melting point ash that 
can easily deposit on boiler tubes. As the deposit layer 
thickens, the gas-side surface temperature increases 
due to the insulating properties of the deposit. Once 
the deposit surface temperature exceeds the ash fusion 
temperature, the deposit becomes sticky, enhancing ash

particle capture. The ash layer can grow very quickly 
and become a plastic molten deposit. The under-slag 
deposit is cooler, solidified and has sufficient structural 
integrity to remain attached to the tube. Slagging occurs 
in the hotter regions of a boiler, typically the furnace and 
sometimes the higher temperature superheater banks. 
Co-firing biomass and coal can further reduce the ash 
melting temperatures and increase furnace slagging. 
Straw and certain biomass species have severe slagging 
characteristics.
Slagging can be controlled with appropriately placed 
sootblowers. (See Chapter 24.) Indirect biomass firing, 
i.e., gasification with gas cleanup, can prevent the slag­
ging concerns that occur with direct-fired combustion 
technologies.
Fouling
Fouling is defined as the formation of high temperature 
bonded deposits on convective tube banks not exposed 
to radiant heat. The deposits form when volatilized ash 
components condense. Since alkali metals generally 
enhance ash volatilization, biomass, when combined 
with coal, has increased fouling tendencies. Ash fouling 
hinders heat transfer, can be corrosive, and degrades 
boiler efficiency. Fouling is controlled with sootblowers. 
Sootblower selection and placement are based on ash 
characteristics and bank arrangement. Indirect firing 
removes ash, precipitates and volatile alkalis in the 
gasifier, minimizing fouling by sending a clean syngas 
to the boiler.
Corrosion
Corrosion-inducing biomass constituents are the 
alkali metals and chlorine. Woody biomass generally 
presents one of the lowest corrosion risks because its 
ash contains low levels of chlorine and alkali. The risk of 
corrosion increases with agricultural fuels and grasses. 
Whereas woody biomass might have 0 to 0.01% of chlorine, 
herbaceous grasses and agricultural residues like straw, 
switchgrass, corn stover and cobs might contain more 
than 0.3% chlorine. Although this seems small, alkali 
chlorides are the most stable chlorine species. Combustion 
vaporizes the alkali chlorides and they condense on the 
boiler tubes as highly aggressive, corrosive deposits, 
especially on high temperature superheater sections. 
The corrosion process involves reactions between the 
tube metal, metal oxides and gaseous chlorine species, 
ultimately forming iron oxide corrosion.
The presence of sulfur can deter the chlorine corrosion 
mechanisms. However, woody biomass ash tends to be 
low in sulfur. An increase in the fuel’s sulfur content 
would decrease the corrosion rate by making the ash more 
stable and harder to melt. Sulfur injection may be used 
to mitigate chlorine corrosion. The Babcock & Wilcox 
Company (B&W) has a sulfur recirculation technology 
for waste-to-energy applications.
Corrosion rates can be controlled by limiting tube 
surface temperatures. A superheater design that limits 
the tube metal temperatures will be less affected by 
corrosion. Parallel and counter flow superheater bank 
arrangements are used to control tube metal tempera­
tures. Select banks will require corrosion resistant tube 
materials. Tube metallurgies high in chromium and 
nickel, typically FeCrNi alloys containing between 20 
and 28% Cr, are the most corrosion resistant.
Erosion
Biomass ash contains erosive constituents and may 
contain tramp material. Erosion rates are affected by 
particulate loading and gas velocity. When biomass is 
harvested, it is often delivered to the power plant with 
dirt, sand and tramp metal. Some of this material may 
be fed to the boiler. On new units, erosion is controlled 
by limiting gas velocities to 50 ft/s (15.2 m/s). This limit 
compensates for fuel variability and upset operating 
conditions. Biomass fuel switch retrofits typically target 
60 ft/s (18.3 m/s) with outage inspection recommendations 
for high gas velocity banks, flues, fans and equipment 
upstream of particulate capture devices.
Uncontrolled emissions
The combustion process produces hot gases and 
particulate commensurate with the fuel’s constituents, 
combustion equipment, stoichiometry and furnace con­
figuration. The products of combustion must be controlled 
to permitted values. Estimates of uncontrolled NOx, CO 
and sulfur dioxide (SO2) emissions provide insight for fuel, 
combustion technology and post-combustion emissions 
control decisions.
Biomass-generated NOx emissions are low compared 
with those from fossil fuels. Combustion temperatures are 
sufficiently low and little thermal NOx is formed from the 
nitrogen in the combustion air. NOx emissions are there­
fore predominantly a function of the fuel nitrogen content. 
(See Chapter 33.) Conversion of fuel-bound nitrogen to 
NOx is dependent on a number of operating conditions 
including excess air, air staging, heat release rate, fuel 
sizing and moisture content. All factors considered, 
NOx emissions from grate firing of most woody biomass 
typically vary between 0.2 and 0.35 lb/106 Btu (260 to 460 
mg/Nm3 at 6% O2) heat input. Fuel contaminants that 
introduce nitrogen compounds (glues and chemicals, for 
example) should receive special consideration.
Woody biomass typically contains 0.0 to 0.1% elemen­
tal sulfur on a dry basis. During the combustion process 
some of this sulfur can be converted to gaseous SO2, but 
the conversion ratio is typically low (10 to 30%). Because 
the quantities of both wood sulfur and gaseous SO2 are 
near the lower detection limit of monitoring instruments, 
correlation of the two is not practical. Typically, SO2 
emissions for grate-fired biomass fuels do not exceed 0.03 
lb/106 Btu (40 mg/Nm3 at 6% O2) heat input. Particular 
attention should be given to fuels where sulfur-bearing 
contaminants may be present.
CO emissions from biomass firing are usually more 
variable. Representing incomplete combustion, CO 
is dependent on time, temperature, turbulence and 
stoichiometry considerations. At normal excess air levels, 
heating value consistency and air-fuel distribution are 
the most predominant determinants of CO emissions. 
Conditions of high or low excess air, high fuel moisture 
and reduced load (<70% of MCR) have all been demon­
strated to increase gaseous CO concentrations. Modern 
grate-fired biomass units at steady operating conditions 
typically emit CO in the range of 0.1 to 0.5 lb/106 Btu (130 
to 650 mg/Nm3 at 6% O2) heat input.

Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are also gaseous 
products of incomplete combustion. As such, VOC emis­
sions are influenced by the same factors affecting CO. 
Typically, VOC emissions while firing biomass fuels do 
not exceed 0.05 lb/106 Btu (65 mg/Nm3 at 6% O2) heat 
input, expressed as methane.
Air Emissions Control Systems
Policymakers and regulatory agencies are advocating 
for increasingly more stringent emissions targets. 
Emissions challenges arise due to the inherent nature 
of biomass. Biomass particle sizing, changeable moisture 
and intermittent/variable biomass input are transient 
conditions that must be addressed. Reducing NOx and 
SO2, minimizing CO through proper air-fuel balance, and 
minimizing unburned carbon through proper fuel sizing 
should all be considered when choosing air emissions 
control systems.
Mechanical dust collectors (MDC) are often installed 
after the last boiler heat trap to collect larger sized 
particulate. The MDC is comprised of multiple cyclone 
tubes enclosed in a casing structure. (See Chapter 32.) 
The cyclone tubes separate the heavy particulate from 
the lighter fraction. The heavier particulate is often 
reinjected into the furnace to improve boiler efficiency. 
Mechanical dust collector efficiency typically ranges 
from 65 to 75% with an approximate draft loss of 2.5 to 
3.0 in. wg (0.62 to 0.75 kPa). High hardness (450 Brinell) 
abrasion resistant material is used in select areas for 
erosion protection.
Small particulate is captured by an electrostatic 
precipitator (ESP) or fabric filter dust collector. Within 
an ESP, uncharged flyash is given a negative charge 
and collected on positively charged plates. A rapping 
system removes the collected ash. ESPs are located 
downstream of the mechanical collector, if installed, 
and are the last particulate control device before the 
stack. (See Chapter 32.)
Because fluidized-bed boilers achieve better carbon 
utilization than grate-fired units, fabric filter dust 
collectors (Chapter 32) are often used for particulate 
capture. Fabric filters are more efficient than ESPs and 
can also reduce other pollutants like hydrogen chloride 
(HCl) and SO2. The development of high temperature, 
high efficiency bag materials has broadened the use of 
fabric filter dust collectors.
Stoichiometry controls NOx. A staged combustion 
air system provides approximately 15 to 25% NOx 
reduction. Historically, post-combustion NOx control 
on biomass boilers (if required) was achieved with 
selective noncatalytic reduction (SNCR) technology. 
(See Chapter 33.) The SNCR process injects a reagent 
into the furnace at a 1600 to 1900F (871 to 1038C) gas 
temperature window to reduce uncontrolled NOx while 
producing water vapor and nitrogen. There are limits 
to the amount of NOx reduction achievable with SNCR 
systems. Reagent mixing and residence time (within the 
necessary temperature window) are critical for obtaining 
desired NOx reduction levels while limiting the unreacted 
ammonia leaving the furnace (defined as ammonia slip).
Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology (Chapter 
33) can achieve higher NOx reduction with lower ammonia 
slip than SNCR systems. The conventional high dust SCR 
arrangement common on PC-fired units injects ammonia 
in a 600 to 750F (316 to 399C) temperature window 
upstream of a catalyst surface. The ammonia reacts 
with the NOx to produce water vapor and nitrogen. SCR 
catalyst may deactivate due to biomass flyash poisoning 
and unburned carbon carryover. For this reason, high 
dust SCRs are uncommon on biomass-fired units. An 
alternative arrangement is to place the SCR downstream 
of a particulate collection device as shown in Fig. 11.
Woody biomass has low sulfur content, and inherent 
wood ash alkalis provide some SO2 and HCl emissions 
reduction. But some biomass can have relatively high 
sulfur and chlorine contents. In this case, SO2 control can 
be accomplished with dry sorbent injection. (See Chapter 
34.) As an added benefit, excess SO2 reagent reduces HCl 
emissions given the correct temperature window. The use 
of a fabric filter dust collector enhances SO2 and acid gas 
removal due to the intimate gas-to-solids contact created 
within the filter cake.
